prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 Line Search - HeLMS
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Redshift search in the HeLMS field

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our goal is to use spectral scans to determine the redshifts of our source using CO and/or CI lines. These will lie within our Band 3 scans over the full range of plausible redshifts for these sources of z=3.5 to 7.
Spectral/Spatial Resolution: We do not seek spatially resolved imaging of our sources in this proposal, so request the lowest resolution arrangement (C34-1). Our sources will not be extended at this resolution, as confirmed by previous interferometry with PdBI and/or SMA. The line search will produce more than adequate uv coverage to achieve our goals. Our expected line widths are ~140 MHz, so TDM mode (with its reduced data rate) is sufficient. Our sources are not expected to be polarized, and their positions are known to much better than the primary beam size (from 4 to better than 0.5 arcseconds).
Sensitivity:
We compute target sensitivities using observed line-strength distributions (SLEDs) from four similarly (intrinsically) luminous DSFGs with well observed SLEDs: the Cosmic Eyelash (z = 2.3; Danielson et al. 2011), ID141 (z = 4.2; Cox et al. 2011), our z = 6.3 source, FLS3 (Riechers et al. 2013), and HLSW01 (z = 3.0; Scott et al. 2011). The fact that most are lensed does not affect this analysis. We have filled in missing 12CO line strengths where necessary by applying the results of (literature) large-velocity gradient models to each source. At each redshift we correct for the luminosity distance, scale the IR luminosity of each template to match the observed 500 micron flux using a dust SED model typical of our sources (Dowell et al. 2014), then compute which lines fall within band 3. We assume a line width of 500 km/s, typical of DSFGs. We track the highest required sensitivity over all templates and redshifts, and use the most stringent as our sensitivity goal. We require a S/N of 7 or greater integrated over the FWHM of each line for the brighter line, and 5 or greater for the fainter. The latter generally sets the overall requirement. Simulations and experience from AO2, where we requested similar line and continuum rms in band 3 spectral scans (see Fig. 1), confirm this S/N and continuum contrast is sufficient to determine redshifts. The predicted continuum flux densities follows from the same computation. The validity of the results of this calculation are demonstrated by our success in detecting CO lines and determining redshifts in our AO2 observations.
As an example of the calculation, for HeLMS_182 (which has a 500 micron continuum flux density of 74 mJy), the ID141 template sets the most stringent sensitivity requirement at z=4.5 to 4.8. This results in a sensitivity goal of 1.0 mJy per 31.25 MHz resolution element. This target is fainter than the other source (HELMS_38), so sets the overall requirement for this science goal. Using the observed 870um flux density instead of 500um for scaling gives a similar result.
Note that our S/N requirements (7 and 5 for the brighter/fainter of the two lines we need to measure the redshift) are for the flux integrated over the full line, not the peak line flux which the OT uses to estimate the S/N. Hence, the value reported for the line S/N by the OT is not the relevant value for our purposes.

This project aims to detect emission lines to measure redshifts. We need to determine line centre and width and this set up is sufficient for that goal while maximising the signal to noise of the line.
We do not need to resolve our sources for the goals of this project. The 4" resolution requested will encompass the entire source, maximising the signal for our spectroscopic observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 Line Search - CDFS
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Redshift search in the CDFS field

As an example of the calculation, for CDFS_40 (which has a 500 micron continuum flux density of 41 mJy), the ID141 template sets the most stringent sensitivity requirement at z=4.5 to 4.8. Using the observed 870um flux density instead of 500um for scaling gives a similar result.
Note that our S/N requirements (7 and 5 for the brighter/fainter of the two lines we need to measure the redshift) are for the flux integrated over the full line, not the peak line flux which the OT uses to estimate the S/N. Hence, the value reported for the line S/N by the OT is not the relevant value for our purposes.

This project aims to detect emission lines to measure redshifts. We need to determine line centre and width anf this set up is sufficient for that goal while maximising the signal to noise of the line.
We do not need to resolve the sources for the goals of the project. The 4" resolution requested is sufficient to encompass the enture source.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 Line Search - H-ATLAS 9h field

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 Line Search - H-ATLAS 12h field
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Redshift search in the H-ATLAS 12h field

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We have developed a technique to robustly select high-z (>4) dusty, massive, star forming galaxies using far-IR Herschel/SPIRE data. Follow up of the first of these sources has proven this technique to be both efficient and reliable, yet the existence of these sources is emphatically not predicted by current models. We have extended the technique by selecting the 'reddest of the red' sources which are likely to be at even higher-z and to present even stronger tests of models. Our first ALMA followup of these sources has confirmed that nearly all lie at z>4 and nearly half lie at z>5. We here propose to extend our ALMA spectroscopy of candidate z>5 ultrared sources selected form HerMES and H-ATLAS surveys to provide still more precise and stringent tests of galaxy formation models.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
